qas.question: The uniqueness of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is due to its high level of what type of molecule?
Is the division rate of the TB bacterium fast or slow relative to other bacteria?
In nature, what "helper" does the MTB bacterium require to grow?
How long is the period between division of MTB cells?
How much time does it take most bacteria to divide?
What is the main cause of Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
How long can a Gram stain last?
What grows outside of the cells of a host organism?
What divides faster than other bacteria?

context: The main cause of <b5_0>TB<b5_0/> is <b9_0>Mycobacterium tuberculosis<b9_0/>, a small, aerobic, nonmotile bacillus. The high <a0_0>lipid<a0_0/> content of this pathogen accounts for many of its unique clinical characteristics. It divides <b8_0>every <a3_0>16 to 20 hours<b8_0/><a3_0/>, which is an extremely <a1_0>slow<a1_0/> rate compared with other bacteria, which usually divide in <a4_0>less than an hour<a4_0/>. Mycobacteria have an outer membrane lipid bilayer. If a Gram stain is performed, MTB either stains very weakly "Gram-positive" or does not retain dye as a result of the high lipid and mycolic acid content of its cell wall. MTB can withstand weak disinfectants and survive in a dry state for <b6_0>weeks<b6_0/>. In nature, the bacterium can grow only within the cells of <a2_0>a host organism<a2_0/>, but <b7_0>M. tuberculosis<b7_0/> can be cultured in the laboratory.
